supporting_quotes: In 2004, Mulligan made her stage debut in the play Forty Winks at the Royal Court Theatre in London.
She made her film debut the following year in Joe Wright's 2005 film adaptation of the Jane Austen novel Pride & Prejudice, portraying Kitty Bennet alongside Keira Knightley.
Later that year, she won the role of orphan Ada Clare in the BAFTA award-winning BBC adaption of Charles Dickens' Bleak House, her television debut.

roles: Best Female Performance in a 2007 Science Fiction Television Episode winner
supporting_quotes: and the Doctor Who episode 'Blink', which won her the Constellation Award for Best Female Performance in a 2007 Science Fiction Television Episode.
She made her Broadway debut playing Nina in the revival of Anton Chekhov's The Seagull (2008).
For her debut Broadway performance in the 2008 American transfer of The Seagull, she was nominated for a Drama Desk Award

roles: BAFTA Award for Best Actress winner
supporting_quotes: Mulligan's breakthrough role came as a 1960s schoolgirl in the coming-of-age film An Education (2009), for which she won the BAFTA Award for Best Actress

roles: Academy Award for Best Actress nominee
supporting_quotes: and received a nomination for the Academy Award for Best Actress.
Mulligan received a nomination for the BAFTA Rising Star Award, which is voted on by the British public.

organizations: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
supporting_quotes: In 2010, she was invited to join the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

That same year she starred in the film adaptation of Kazuo Ishiguro's acclaimed novel Never Let Me Go with Keira Knightley, and Andrew Garfield. She won a British Independent Award for her performance.
She returned to the stage in the Atlantic Theater Company's off-Broadway play adaptation of Ingmar Bergman's Through a Glass, Darkly, from 13 May – 3 July 2011.

roles: Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Actress in a Play nominee
supporting_quotes: For her performance she was nominated for the Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Actress in a Play.

roles: BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role nominee
supporting_quotes: She received her second nomination for the BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role—for the film Drive

roles: BIFA for Best Supporting Actress nominee
supporting_quotes: For her performance in Shame, she received critical praise as well as a nomination for the BIFA for Best Supporting Actress.
In May 2012, she was a co-chair, alongside Anna Wintour, for the 2012 Met Ball Gala themed Schiaparelli and Prada: Impossible Conversations.
Mulligan became the ambassador of the Alzheimer's Society in 2012, with the goal of raising awareness and research funding for Alzheimers and dementia.
Mulligan has been an ambassador for the Alzheimer's Society since 2012
In 2014, Mulligan became an ambassador for the charity War Child
and an ambassador for War Child since 2014

In 2014, she returned to the stage, starring in the London revival of the David Hare play Skylight with Bill Nighy and Matthew Beard, directed by Stephen Daldry, at Wyndham's Theatre in London's West End.
It won the 2014 Evening Standard Theatre Award for Revival of the Year
and was nominated for the 2014 Olivier Award for Best Revival.
She followed the production when it transferred to Broadway at the John Golden Theatre in April 2015.

roles: Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading Actress in a Play nominee
supporting_quotes: she earned her first Tony Award nomination for Best Performance by a Leading Actress in a Play.
She was appointed Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in 2025 for services to drama.

roles: Independent Spirit Award for Best Female Lead nominee
supporting_quotes: For her performance, Mulligan received a nomination for the Independent Spirit Award for Best Female Lead.
Mulligan stepped back into television as a Detective Inspector in Collateral, a BBC Two limited series
Mulligan starred off Broadway in the solo show, Girls and Boys at the Minetta Lane Theatre.

roles: Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Solo Performance nominee
supporting_quotes: She was nominated for the Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Solo Performance.
In 2020, Mulligan starred in Emerald Fennell's black comedy thriller film Promising Young Woman, alongside Bo Burnham and Alison Brie. She also served as an executive producer on the film

roles: Academy Award for Best Actress nominee
supporting_quotes: For her performance, she received her second nomination for the Academy Award for Best Actress

After winning Best Female Lead at the 36th Independent Spirit Awards, Mulligan dedicated her award to the late Helen McCrory.

roles: Academy Award for Best Actress nominee

The film premiered at the Sundance Film Festival on January 25, 2025.
Mulligan will also star on the second season of Netflix's anthology series Beef, alongside Oscar Isaac, Cailee Spaeny, Charles Melton.
In May 2025, she joined Greta Gerwig's The Chronicles of Narnia film adaptation, which is titled Narnia: The Magician's Nephew
She will have a voice role in Laika's stop motion animated feature Wildwood
As a teenager, she was educated at Woldingham School, an independent school in Surrey.
She was the student head of the drama department there, performing in plays and musicals
During her late teens and early twenties, she worked as a pub barmaid and an errand-runner for Ealing Studios between acting jobs.
